title: 103_hr289
content: The Act defines key terms such as "enrollee" and "health benefits plan" according to chapter 89 of title 5, United States Code. The Office of Personnel Management will conduct a demonstration project in 1994 and 1995 to assess the feasibility of including benefits for drug and alcohol abuse treatment under federal employee health insurance. The demonstration project in 1994 and 1995 will involve various employee health insurance plans, including the service benefit plan, indemnity benefit plan, employee organization plans, and comprehensive medical plans with the largest enrollments. The demonstration project in 1994 and 1995 will involve employee health insurance plans within specific metropolitan statistical areas, including Portland, Oregon. The demonstration project in 1994 and 1995 will involve employee health insurance plans within specific metropolitan statistical areas, including Portland, Oregon. Inclusion under paragraph (1) unless area has 10,000 to 25,000 employees and annuitants. SEC. 4. BENEFITS. Under the demonstration project, contracts between the Office of Personnel Management and carriers offering a specific plan must include benefits such as inpatient detoxification, patient assessment, outpatient therapy, inpatient therapy, follow-up counseling, and family counseling for individuals with substance abuse problems. The demonstration project contracts may include benefits for related support services, such as child care or other dependent care. The Office of Personnel Management will consult with carriers, labor organizations, and agency heads regarding determinations, benefit terms, and other matters related to the demonstration project. Coordination with other government programs will also be ensured. SEC. 6. The Office of Personnel Management will coordinate the demonstration project with various government programs related to drug and alcohol abuse. SEC. 7. Evaluation and reporting requirements will be implemented. The Office of Personnel Management will contract for periodic evaluations of the demonstration project regarding cost, efficacy, employee productivity, and the possibility of offering project benefits more broadly. Reporting requirements mandate an interim report submission by March 15, 1996, to specific congressional committees. The Senate will receive a final report on the demonstration project by April 1, 1997, which will include the most recent evaluation received by the Office. SEC. 8. FUNDING. Individual and Government contributions under section 8906 of title 5, United States Code, shall be determined without considering the provisions of this Act. Authorization of appropriations for necessary expenses to carry out this Act is granted.
